questions.text: Which autopsy technique involves en masse removal of organs, extending from the tongue down to the prostate?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from the tongue to the prostate.

Methods of Autopsy

  1. Virchow's Method (M/C)
    • One-by-one organ removal. (Option A ruled out)
    • Fast and easy.
    • Typically used for general autopsies.
  2. Ghon's/en-Block Method
    • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option C ruled out)
    • Organ relations remain intact.
    • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
    • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.
  3. Lettule's/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option D)
    • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
    • Complete viscera removal.
    • Blood vessels and vascular supply are intact.
    • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.
  4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option B ruled out)
    1. Inside dissection.
    2. Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
    3. Highly transmissible diseases.
    4. Also used for infants <1 year to minimise contamination risk.

Reference:

An Introduction to Autopsy Technique, sample

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with known HIV infection has passed away, and the body is submitted for post-mortem examination. Which autopsy method is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Rokitansky's technique is used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).

Methods of Autopsy:

  1. Virchow's Method (M/C)
    • One-by-one organ removal. (Option C ruled out)
    • Fast and easy.
    • Typically used for general autopsies.
  2. Ghon's/en-Block Method
    • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option A ruled out)
    • Organ relations remain intact.
    • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
    • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.
  3. Lettule's/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out)
    • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
    • Complete viscera removal.
    • Blood vessels and vascular supply are intact.
    • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.
  4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D)
    • Inside dissection.
    • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
    • Highly transmissible diseases.
    • Also used for infants <1 year to minimise contamination risk.

Reference:

An Introduction to Autopsy Technique, sample

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with difficulty walking and pain in the perianal region. A specimen taken from the perianal area, when tested, produces yellow, needle-shaped rhombic crystals upon reaction with picric acid. What test was performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The above scenario is suggestive of the Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.

  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Explanation for other options:

Teichmann test (Option C): This test detects haemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

Acid phosphatase test (Option D): The Acid phosphatase test is used to detect the presence of prostatic fluid in sexual assault cases. It does not produce needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid.

Reference:

  1. Acid phosphatases - PMC

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with multiple seizure episodes. He remains conscious between the episodes and has been using herbal remedies for treatment. During the seizures, there is noticeable arching of the back. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Strychnine poisoning is characterised by seizures and muscle spasms, often causing arching of the back (opisthotonus).

  • The patient is typically conscious between episodes, and the seizures are triggered by minimal stimuli.
  • Strychnine is a potent neurotoxin that acts by blocking inhibitory neurotransmission, leading to overstimulation of the central nervous system.

Explanation for other options:

Ricinus (Option B): Ricinus, derived from the castor bean plant, contains ricin, which causes gastrointestinal symptoms, organ failure, and hemorrhagic shock. It does not typically cause seizures with back arching.

Nerium odorum (Option C): Nerium odorum (oleander) contains cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart and can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and potentially death. Seizures and back arching are not characteristic features of oleander poisoning.

Datura (Option D): Datura contains tropane alkaloids, which cause delirium, hallucinations, and anticholinergic toxicity. Although it can cause seizures, it is not typically associated with arching of the back or the pattern of seizures described here.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Causing a miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing a miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by an act done with the intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 of the Indian Penal Code pertains to which of the following legal issues?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 314 IPC: Death caused by an act done with the intent to cause miscarriage, if the act is done without the woman's consent. Now it corresponds to BNS 90.

Reference

  1. THE INDIAN PENAL CODE ARRANGEMENT OF SECTIONS-CHAPTER I CHAPTER II (Page 8)
  2. CORRESPONDENCE TABLE and COMPARISON SUMMARY OF THE BHARTATIYA NYAYA SANHITA, 2023 (BNS) to THE INDIAN PENAL CODE, 1860 (IPC)

questions.text: A deceased individual is found to have a body temperature of 39°C during examination. What is the most likely explanation for this elevated postmortem temperature?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Septicemia, which is a systemic infection with widespread inflammation, is a common cause of fever in both living and deceased individuals.

  • It can cause hyperthermia due to the body's inflammatory response.
  • Elevated body temperature within the first two hours after death points toward a diagnosis of Postmortem caloricity.

Postmortem Caloricity:

  • Refers to the condition where the body temperature remains elevated for the first two hours after death.

Note: Burns do not typically cause postmortem caloricity.

Explanation for other options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option A): Cyanide poisoning typically causes rapid death and may lead to hypothermia rather than fever. Cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to metabolic acidosis, but does not usually result in a fever like septicemia.

Corrosive poisoning (Option C): Corrosive poisoning (e.g., acid or alkali ingestion) can cause significant damage to tissues, but it does not typically result in a high body temperature like 39°C. It might lead to shock and other complications, but fever is not the hallmark sign.

Intra-abdominal haemorrhage (Option D): Intra-abdominal haemorrhage typically results in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss, leading to low body temperature (hypothermia) rather than fever.

questions.text: While resting in his field, a farmer suddenly experienced a sharp pain in his leg and noticed a fast-moving creature retreating. Soon after, he became drowsy and was taken to the hospital. Examination revealed persistent bleeding at the bite site, localised pain, redness, and blister formation. What is the most probable cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The symptoms described, including drowsiness, pain around the wound, bleeding, and blisters, are consistent with a viper bite.

  • Viper bites often lead to profuse bleeding due to the effects of venom-induced coagulopathy.

Explanation for other options:

Cobra (Option B): Cobra bites are primarily neurotoxic, causing paralysis, respiratory distress, and potentially death if untreated. While cobras can cause pain and local swelling, they do not typically cause the extensive bleeding or blisters seen with viper bites. Cobras do not usually cause such local tissue necrosis and blistering.

Wasp bite (Option C): Wasp stings can cause pain, redness, and swelling at the sting site, but they typically do not lead to bleeding, drowsiness, or blisters. The symptoms described here are more consistent with a venomous bite from a snake rather than an insect sting.

Scorpion (Option D): While scorpion stings can cause pain, local swelling, and sometimes neurological symptoms (such as drowsiness), they typically do not cause blisters or profuse bleeding at the sting site.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia, which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary oedema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

Key Takeaways:
